animalOfTheDay.name: squid
facts: Squid have three hearts: two pump blood to the gills, and one pumps it to the rest of the body.
They can change color rapidly to communicate or camouflage, using specialized cells called chromatophores.
Some squid species can 'fly' by propelling themselves out of the water and gliding for short distances.
The giant squid is the largest invertebrate, with eyes the size of dinner plates.

calendar.name: siberian husky
facts: They are known for their striking blue or multi-colored eyes and thick double coat.
Siberian huskies are a medium-sized working dog breed.
They are energetic and require a lot of exercise.
Siberian huskies were originally bred as sled dogs.

calendar.name: skunk
facts: Before spraying, skunks usually give a warning by stomping their feet or raising their tail.
Skunks are nocturnal and have poor eyesight but an excellent sense of smell and hearing.
They are immune to snake venom and will sometimes eat venomous snakes.
Skunks are known for their ability to spray a foul-smelling liquid as a defense mechanism, which can reach up to 10 feet.

calendar.name: snail
facts: The largest land snail, the African giant snail, can grow up to 15 inches long.
Snails can sleep for up to three years if the weather isn't favorable.
They have thousands of tiny teeth on their tongue-like radula, which they use to scrape food.
Snails are hermaphrodites, meaning each individual has both male and female reproductive organs.

calendar.name: snow leopard
facts: They are unable to roar but communicate with chuffing sounds and growls.
Snow leopards can leap up to 50 feet in a single bound.
They have thick fur and wide, fur-covered feet that act as natural snowshoes.
Snow leopards are known as 'ghosts of the mountains' due to their elusive nature.

calendar.name: snowy owl
facts: Snowy owls can detect prey moving beneath the snow using their exceptional hearing.
Their feathers are nearly entirely white, providing perfect camouflage in snowy environments.
Unlike most owls, they are diurnal and hunt both day and night in the Arctic tundra.
Snowy owls are one of the largest owl species, with a wingspan of up to 5 feet.

calendar.name: spider
facts: All spiders produce silk, but not all spiders spin webs to catch prey.
Spiders are not insects; they are arachnids, with eight legs and two body segments.
Some spiders can 'balloon' by releasing silk threads to catch the wind and travel long distances.
The venom of most spiders is harmless to humans, with only a few species being dangerous.

calendar.name: squid
facts: They can change color rapidly to communicate or camouflage, using specialized cells called chromatophores.
The giant squid is the largest invertebrate, with eyes the size of dinner plates.
Squid have three hearts: two pump blood to the gills, and one pumps it to the rest of the body.
Some squid species can 'fly' by propelling themselves out of the water and gliding for short distances.

randomAnimals.name: civet
facts: Kopi Luwak coffee, one of the most expensive coffees in the world, is produced from beans that have been digested and excreted by civets.
They are omnivorous, eating fruits, insects, small mammals, and birds.
Most species are nocturnal and arboreal, although some are more terrestrial.
Civets are cat-like mammals from Africa and Asia, known for their ability to secrete a musky scent, used in perfumery.

randomAnimals.name: jaguar
facts: Their spots, called rosettes, are unique to each individual, like fingerprints.
Jaguars are excellent swimmers and often hunt fish, turtles, and caimans.
They have the strongest bite force of any big cat, capable of crushing skulls.
Jaguars are the largest big cats in the Americas and the third-largest in the world.

randomAnimals.name: bee-eater
facts: Before eating an insect, a bee-eater will rub it against a branch to remove the stinger and venom.
They are social birds, often nesting in colonies and foraging in groups.
Bee-eaters are known for their vibrant plumage and their ability to catch insects, especially bees and wasps, in mid-flight.
Most bee-eater species build their nests in burrows dug into the ground or in sandbanks.
